transcript.title: Republican Party of Minnesota v. White

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now on number oh one five twenty-one, The Republican Party of Minnesota, et al., versus Verna Kelly.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court: Like most states Minnesota selects its judges through periodic popular elections.
And when candidates' speech is severely restricted, the peoper [: people] are denied access to the information they need to make an informed choice.
While state court judges are different from other elected officials, Minnesota's Announce Clause, as now interpreted by its supreme court, goes too far resulting in elections without campaign.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Could we find out from you just what the Announce Clause prohibits that isn't already prohibited by the Pledges and Promises Clause, as it's been interpreted?

The Announce Clause c- prohibits, according to the decision of the Eighth Circuit, any general dis- allows general discussions of the law, while it prohibits any implying of how a person would rule a candidate would rule, on an issue or case before the Court.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How does that differ, then, from the Pledges or Promises Clause?
The Predges [: Pledges] and Promises Clause prohibits any pledge or promise that other than faithful performance of duties in office.

The difference between announce, the plain language of the clause, and pledge or promise announce is simply making known, is one of the formulations of the Eighth Circuit, or implying while pledging or promising is making a commitment on how you would rule in a future case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you think the Announce Clause, even as interpreted by the Eighth Circuit to be the same as the ABA canon, goes beyond that?
Well, Your Honor, there is one aspect of the current nineteen ninety ABA can- n- canon that has was not discussed by the Ninth Circuit or by the ABA brief.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: does that appear in your brief? Where where is the ABA canon we're talking about? Where is it? I want to look at it while you're talking about it.
I do not have a reference to the ABA canon, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: say that it was that Minnesota's provision is the same as the ABA canon, right?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: ABA canon re- prohibits candidates, judicial candidates, from making statements that commit or appear to commit the candidate.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that looks very much like the Pledge or Promise language.

Well, one of the problems, Your Honor, is that the January twenty-ninth opinion of the Minnesota Supreme Court interpreting the Announce Clause adopted the Eighth Circuit opinion and and its interpretations.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Unfortunately, the Eighth Circuit had conflicting statements about the scope of the of the interpretation that it was announcing.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you're you s- appear to be arguing, in your brief at least, that the Announce Clause is unconstitutionally vague, is...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But did you make that argument below?
Yes, we did, as to the interpretation proffered in the district court, adding the words likely to come before the Court.
canon, even though it was not advocated by any of the parties.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You didn't include a vagueness challenge in your petition for certiorari, did you?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is it in the question on which we granted cert, do you think?
No, but it is encompassed within the v- violation of the First Amendment that we alleged.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: thought vagueness was a First Amendment issue.

Well, in the context of First Amendment protected speech, a a a something that chills First Amendment speech, but because of it is a vague rur- rule and therefore does not provide a bright line necessary for the exercise of that speech, that it it constitutes a First Amendment violation.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: W- one of the statements that the Eighth Circuit and I don't have the citation to the brief I have the citation to the Federal Third two forty-seven federal third eight eighty-one.
That is one of the three...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: we could d- d- d- would you agree that that's perhaps the narrowest of the th- three constructions? I w- I want to find wh- what might be the most likely statement to survive review and then have you discuss that, because I I take it you would not be you w- you would not agree that even that is constitutional.
It is not the narrowest, Your Honor, because it uses the word issue.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: in the Eighth Circuit case where they use the word decide a case, such as on page forty-five A of the petition the petition appendix.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: let's take the let's take the last one.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: w- w- Would you agree th- that that would be a constitutional standard if it were part of a code of judicial ethics that applied to the judge after the judge was on the bench?
No, and but I believe that this canon does apply to judges once they er are elected and on the bench.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: uh-huh Well, are judges, after they are on the bench, subject to, have all of the same rights they have before they go on the bench, insofar as making public comments?
No, they may be limited in a number of different ways, Your Honor, that are are necessary to advance compelling interests.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: uh-huh Well, why why is it that, i- if th- an election is in July, the State can, under your view, not prohibit statements in June before he's elected, but they can prohibit the statements in August, after he's elected?

Well, well Your Honor, the First Amendment applied has its most urgent application in campaigns for for elections, and it is ne- and while ju- both judges and judicial candidates may be limited in their speech, it has never been held that simply announcing your views on a disputed legal or political issue constitutes a eh- an indication of partiality such that would justify, for instance, recusal or...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought you said it'd be okay.
Well, the- then I then I I then I misspoke, is that if that was your...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: incorporation doctrine or substantive due process and so forth...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you could prohibit judges from discussing...
Canon four and in C- fact, Canon four B of the Minnesota canons encourages judges to propose changes in the substantive and procedural law, even individually.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: judges sitting judges run for election.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Because see, sitting judge could not be restricted, could he or she, in a way?
sitting judges are restricted, for instance, from commenting on pending cases that are pending before them, quite properly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You wouldn't object to to candidates being prohibited from commenting about particular cases either, would you?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: take your objection to be that you you say you know there's this case pending in the courts.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you gave the examples for your one of the briefs gave examples of commenting on specific decisions that had been rendered by the Minnesota Supreme Court and you said that restraint on that comment was impermissable.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: distinction you're making between past cases and pending cases in the court, that that that that are likely to come before you if you're elected.
Yes, I the First Amendment protects discussion of p- past cases.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: S- s- supposing that a c- supposing that Minnesota the Minnesota Supreme Court had announced that its Fourth Amendment was more protective than the federal Fourth Amendment and a candidate running for that courts saw that several cases, the evidence had been suppressed in Minnesota courts, the defendant was acquitted, so he said, I think we should go back to the idea that our Fourth Amendment is the same as the federal Fourth Amendment.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Not if it's considered implying how you would rule in a future case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: we know that mm do we is there any mechanism for getting clarification? And the big problem in this case is this is a frontal attack, and so we have no specific examples.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You can seek a private advisory opinion that is not binding on either the office or the board.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Bopp I I would assume your answer would be that if it's too too fuzzy for us to understand what it means in order to rule upon its constitutionality, it's also too fuzzy for a judicial candidate to to know what it means in order to conform his conduct to it and, therefore, unconstitutional.
Yes, sir, Your Honor, not only to candidates, but this canon binds the family members, the sup- supporters of the candidate.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I still want to make clear your your posi- Your position is is that the judge can, after the judge's election, be disciplined, sanctioned for certain remarks that he could not be sanctioned bef- for before the election.
N- N- No, Your Honor, and if I gave you that impression, I...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: post and pre election that have r-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, do you claim that the candidate...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then it it's just then your position is it i- is that there is a difference as it applies to pending cases as to which a sitting judge has to to which a sitting judge has been assigned.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are there limits on what a candidate can say?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It is in the realm of P- Pledges and Promises.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Suppose he said, There are a lot of criminal cases pending, and, to take the Chief Justice's hypothetical, we've gone too far in interpreting the Fourth Amendment, and I'm going to be more strict.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, that c- that is allowed, Your Honor, because he's not promising certain results in a particular case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: when these cases bef- come before me, this is what I'll do.
Then that is a pledge or promise of...

text_blocks.text: Well, Your Honor, there's a le- a public perception of the impartiality of the judiciary that I think properly can be taken into account.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And I think this rule announces a rule that is consistent with the judge judge's obligation to decide cases in accordance with...

text_blocks.text: that's an extremely fine line you're drawing, it seems to me, because I think a moment ago, in response to my question, you said that a candidate would be prohibited, and wrongly prohibited, under y- your view on your your view of the thing from saying that Minnesota should adopt the fe- federal Fourth Amendment standard rather than the more liberal Fourth Amendment standard that the Supreme Court of Minnesota hypothetically had it.
He is not, under th- the well, to the extent that we know what the Announce Clause means...

it would imply what he would rule in the future.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: an- you an- y- an- you say that the First Amendment prohibits that?
No, I'd say the First Amendment protects talking about prior decisions.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is we're talking about the rule the Minnesota rule versus...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: comment on on a ca- by a candidate who is not yet a judge on a case which is then pending before the court? In In your view, can the State prohibit the candidate from saying, I've been reading about this case.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, there would there would seem to be, under Gentile, more leeway for a lawyer not in a pending case to discuss a pending case.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What's the answer to my question?
I think I think it could not be prohibited.

text_blocks.text: In In the question that the Chief Justice asked, suppose the judge said, I pledge and promise that if you elect me, I will vote in every Fourth Amendment case to restore the law to what it was.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: go on that to the Announce.

text_blocks.text: That is a classic pledge and promise that I think can be appropriately prohibited under the First Amendment.

text_blocks.text: from that? That is, I read through the Minnesota Bar Association's brief, the ABA's brief, and portions of the Brennen brief.

text_blocks.text: All right? They all suggested to me that this ethical rule, like all ethical rules, is vague, interpreted by interpretive opinions, of which there are many.

i- is that it's you are not right.

You should strike down the Announce Clause, because it it is impossible hopelessly impossible to know what is included within the rule and what is outside the rule.

No, because of the appear to commit language.

A- As I As I interpret it, yes, because the appear to commit takes us back away from a bright line of a pledge or a promise into the realm of implying what you are saying.

the Minnesota rule if you simply imply how you might rule...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: with regard to judicial opinions is is that it is perfectly okay for a sitting judge to make known to the public his view on something like the death penalty when he does it in an opinion and, therefore, that can be out there.

It is perfectly appropriate for a judge to do that in an opinion or in speeches or a lar [: law] review articles.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In speeches? You mean the the judge could could go out and a sitting judge can go out and make a speech and say, In the next death penalty case to come before me, I'm going to vacate.

text_blocks.text: Then, then what he can say in speeches certainly is less than what he can say in a judicial opinion in which he says, I vote to vacate the death penalty because I believe it's unconstitutional.
Y- Yes, I I would think he would.

what the construed rule in Minnesota means.

text_blocks.text: I understand that I've two questions, really.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, what would happen if, instead of my being in the Senate, I had been in an election campaign, and I was trying to draw this very line between s- commitments to future cases, specific ones, and general judicial philosophy.
As a I'm sorry, as a sitting judge, Your Honor?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I I then suppose I won.

text_blocks.text: is what are the consequences? It is, after all, an ethical rule, and ethical rules are often blurry.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And I want to know what would likely happen to a person who makes a mistake in drawing this very fine line, assuming that it's in good faith.

Your Honor, the the Board on Judicial Standards or the Lawyers Board would have jurisdiction with respect to a violation which sounds like a technical violation, as you describe it, and could impose some discipline, but I would suspect that discipline would be very minute, if at all...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

I'm not aware of any authority that would allow a criminal sanction for such a...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Can I ask you one other...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there any authority that a state, under the First Amendment, is free to impose a civil sanction but not a criminal sanction on particular speech?
Y- I'm not aware of authority to that effect either,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This is a technical question, but the the sentence you started out reading from the Eighth Circuit's opinion...

text_blocks.text: construction, Your Honor, is, for all practical purposes, identical to the commitment clause.
M- Mr. Gilbert, may I ask...

You know you can put them together.

And they can say that the the I think the difference of opinion we have here is whether they can go the extra step and just say, And I would t- try to overturn the decision if I'm elected.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Because in a prior opinion, due process was accorded, because the judge actually heard the argument of the litigants, heard the facts and the applicable law.

Y- Your Honor again, this is a balance that's being struck.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Fu- You're saying the public doesn't know enough in order to to to determine whether a judge has the requisite qualifications for office.

text_blocks.text: I'm surprised to hear that, in light of the the...
that is in our brief and other briefs...

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You should go before the Senate...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I actually found that when they approached a particular case about how you were going to decide in the future, both the Senators in my experience, and since it only concerns me would not press the issue of how you would decide a particular case.
and that's why it was difficult to find...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your Honor, cases are made up of issues.

text_blocks.text: Gilbert, do you do you think we should draw any distinction, or whether it would be reasonable for us to draw any distinction, between the the application of the rule to the candidates themselves and the application of the rule to all of these ancillary individuals around them their associates, their families? Let's a- let's assume that we say that the rule passes muster with respect to the candidate.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: because we figure, you know, that's how you get the message out.
Your Honor, n- I don't think so, not at all.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But if the family member says, Well I'm I'm going to tell anyway.
I'm going to tell anyway there's no penalty.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Y- Your Honor, the standard is knowingly permit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: know, in practical terms, what happens.
Your Honor, I'd assume a complaint would not be filed under those circumstances.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I don't I don't know why it why it would...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I mean are are opponents just forgiving of their their opponents in your state?
Well, Your Honor, it's a very difficult standard to satisfy, knowingly permit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, maybe it's difficult to satisfy.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I assume that there could be a complaint, simply based on the emphatic statement of the spouse.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, of course, the burden's on the State.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But the candidate would have to answer.
sometimes doesn't investigate complaints where they don't have sufficient evidence to think there's even a basis...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: evidence in the event that a spouse made an emphatic statement saying, His view is, or Her...
it's conceivable, Your Honor, but, a- again, if the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that pr- is that part of the canon part of the question in this case? I know it's part of the canon.
Your Honor, it's kind of oblique.
the Eighth Circuit dealt with that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, the Your Honor, you're correct.
what the petitioners have done is, they have refused to acknowledge that narrow construction.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: W- W- W- Was not raised where?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: like that about about chilling chilling speech because it's not clear what what the coverage of the of the prohibition is.
Y- Your Honor, in their petition, though, they have not made those kinds of arguments specifically as...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: certainly did in the reply brief.
They have in the reply brief, but not in the petition, which was the question that was asked previously.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I guess you could set up a system where you get advisory opinions, but I don't know that we've ever allowed that to be done in the First Amendment...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: may I say this? You know, you submit what you want to say, and somebody tells you, Yeah, okay.
Well, Your I don't Your Honor, first of all, I'm not a proponent of what of that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: something from the board? If somebody wants to give a speech in a political campaign, I assume you can't get a twelve-hour ruling from the board.
Well, they actually do advisory opinions over the phone, Your Honor, on very short order, and they could do it in a matter of of hours or days, depending upon what the needs are.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Gilbert, you brought out that this is not just a question of th- the candidate informing the voter, that behind all of this is a litigant who's going to be in a future case.
Are you asking in the f-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: be under Minnesota law, a grounds to say, I don't want that judge, because he's announced in the election that he's tough on drunk driving?
No, I don't think so, Your Honor, not under those circumstances.
